details.notes:
• When you transform into your full Owl Form, your arms and wings become one, and Summoned Arrows become Summoned Bombs you can drop on your allies/enemies.

  • Your Primeval Boons are active.
  • Primeval Awareness is passive
  • Additionally you lose access to most ranger abilities, spells, spell slots, and all weapons.
    • Ranger abilities that remain are Spiritual Bond, Natural Explorer Favored Terrains, Favored Enemies.

system.description:
• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Grapple maneuver to grab or wrestle a creature
    • You must have at least one free hand to attempt a grapple, your target must be within your reach, and the target must be no more than one size category larger than you.
      • The target makes a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and the target becomes grappled.
          • In addition to things that end the condition, you can release the target at any time (no action required).
  • Escaping a Grapple
    • While grappled, a creature can use its action to attempt to escape. It must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
  • Moving a Grappled Creature
    • When you move, you can drag or carry the grappled creature with you.
      • When you do so, your Speed is halved, unless the creature's weight is within your carrying capacity and you are not encumbered by bulky items.
  • Freeing a Grappled Creature
    • You can use the Grapple maneuver to try to free another grappled or restrained creature.
      • The creature grappling or restraining the target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • If it fails the saving throw, the grappled or restrained creature is freed.
        • Additionally, you may move the freed creature 5 feet in any direction.

• While you cannot grapple a creature two or more size categories larger than you, you can grab onto it.
    • By jumping onto its back or climbing up a limb, you can make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against the creature's maneuver DC to cling to or balance upon its body.
      • On a success, you move into the creature's space and can move upon its body as if it is difficult terrain.
  • While grabbing onto a larger creature, you gain advantage on attack rolls against it.
    • The larger creature may be able to attack you as normal, depending on its limbs or attacks.
      • It can also use an action or replace one of its attacks on its turn to try to dislodge you, such as shaking you loose or bashing you against a wall, forcing you to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against its maneuver DC or fall prone into the nearest space adjacent to the creature, taking its basic melee damage in the process.
  • If the creature chooses to roll over in order to dislodge you, it becomes prone, but you have disadvantage on the saving throw to hang on.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You may use your Disarm maneuver to attempt to knock an item or weapon from a creature's hand.
    • The target must be within your reach and be holding an item (either carried or wielded).
      • The target makes a Strength or Dexterity saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • The target has advantage if it is larger than you or holding the item with two or more hands
        • Alternatively, a target smaller than you has disadvantage.
          • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and the target drops the item in its space.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Knockdown maneuver to trip or push a creature down.
    • The target must be within your reach and be no more than one size category larger than you.
    • The target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
      • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and knock the target prone.

• You can use an action or bonus action to make an Overrun maneuver to move through a hostile creature's space by forcing your way past.
    • Make a Strength saving throw against the target's maneuver DC.
      • On a success, you deal basic melee damage and can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.
      • The creature can choose to let you pass instead of rolling.
      • You have advantage if you are larger than the target, or disadvantage if you are smaller.
      • If you are two or more sizes smaller than the target, you can move through the hostile creature's space without making a save.
      • You still provoke opportunity attacks if you move beyond a creature's reach.

• If you are able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this maneuver replaces one of them.
  • You can use the Shove maneuver to push a creature away.
    • The target must be within your reach and be no more than one size category larger than you.
      • The target makes a Strength saving throw against your maneuver DC.
        • On a failure, you deal basic melee damage and push the target a number of feet away from you equal to 5 + 5 for every 5 points it failed its saving throw by.
          • You can move the creature in any direction away from you (to the side, forward, or diagonally away).
    • A creature that is shoved off of a precipice is propelled off of whatever it is standing on -- it does not receive any saving throw or ability check to grab onto something to avoid falling down below.
• Advantage on poison saves and poison resistance.

• Lycanthropes are vulnerable to Silvered Weapons.

    • If a Silvered weapon/projectile remains in you at the beginning of your turn, you take 1d6 damage that cannot be reduced in any way.
• If you have a non-incapacitated ally within 5-feet of a creature, you have advantage on attack rolls.

• At 3rd level, your fully transformed Wereform has begun to evolve in a myriad of ways.

    • You may choose 2 Primeval Boons you meet the prerequisites for, which you gain the benefits of while fully transformed.

      • Primeval Boons Found Here: Merrek & Myrra Primeval Boons

        • You gain additional Primeval Boons as you gain levels in this class, as shown below:

          • 3rd Level, 2 Primeval Boons

          • 5th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 7th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 9th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 11th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 15th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 18th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

          • 20th Level, 1 Primeval Boon

        • These Primeval Boons are only active while fully transformed.

        • Choose wisely, because you can’t devolve a Primeval Boons.
• Advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

• At the start of each of your turns, you recover 1d10 HP in your Owl form.

    • Provided you have 1 or more HP and you have not suffered damage from a Silvered or Wolfsbane laced weapon since the start of your last turn.

    • If you are not in initiative, this healing does not function.

• A set of wedding bands was given to Merrek and Myra as a marriage gift, giving them the ability to call forth their summonable items, including clothing.

  • Used to call forth Summoned Arrows into your bow during your Dwarvenguard/Hybrid form.

  • Used to call forth your Collision Crystal Sniper Rifle in your Dwarvenguard/Hybrid form.

• Starting at 2nd level, you have a maximum number of Summoned Bombs you can summon equal to your Ranger level.

    • Firing a Summoned Bombs counts as an attack, even if they are being fired at your allies to bolster them.

    • Myra cannot fire these arrows into herself.

    • You recover a number of Summoned Bombs equal to half your maximum number of arrows, not to exceed your max, after a short rest.

      • For example, if you have a max of 12 and you’ve used 5, you gain 6 during a short rest bringing you to 11.

        • Alternatively, If you were at 10, you only gain 2, bringing you to the max of 12.

    • You recover all Summoned Bombs after a long rest.

• At 2nd level, you may summon an Energizing Bomb from your Wedding Band of Order and shoot it at an ally to give them back some of their primary energy source used for abilities, spells, etc…

    • Merrek +2 Ki

    • Nep Nik +2 Charges

    • Teresa +2 Sorcery Points

    • Mogli +1 Spell Slots
    • Hákarl +5 Agony Pool
    • ??? +5 Blood Pool
• Your Wereform gains a flying speed of +20-feet.
• You don't provoke opportunity attacks when you fly out of an enemies reach.

• Myra can attempt shifting back into her Dwarvenguard Form after she's been transformed for at least one turn.

    • Roll 1d20

      • 1-4: You remain as you are.

      • 5-12: You transform into your Hybrid Form.

      • 13-20: You transform into your Dwarvenguard Form or may choose to transform into your Hybrid Form as a Free Action.
system.prerequisite: 1 Turn Has Passed Since Last Transformation

system.description: • You can see up to 1 mile away with no difficulty, able to discern fine detail as if you were within 5-feet of what you are observing.
• For every 2 feet you fly downwards, you only need to expend 1 foot of movement.

Z1YK6E18JsghqNNl.onSave: They're not tricked by your Mimicry
Z1YK6E18JsghqNNl.label: Mimicry Save

system.description:
• You can mimic sounds you have heard, such as animal noises or words someone has spoken.

    • A creature can tell that they are imitations by succeeding on a Wisdom check against your Dexterity Modifier.

• Weapon Type

    • Natural Melee

  • Reach

    • 5 ft.

  • Targets

    • 1

  • Hit

    • 1d8 + Proficiency + Dexterity Modifier

  • Damage

    • Slashing
  • Description
    • You swoop down and shred an opponent with your talons.

• Weapon Type

    • Natural Melee

  • Reach

    • 5ft

  • Target

    • One

  • Hit

    • 1d6 + Forms Dexterity Modifier Piercing Damage.

    • Attempt to Blind Them until your next turn.

  • Description

    • You attempt to peck or dig your talons into their face to temporarily blind them.

    • If they succeed on a Dexterity Save the target is not blinded, but still takes the full damage.

• Allows a character to evade opportunity attacks for the rest of their turn.
    • It’s a defensive tactic used when you want to safely move away from an enemy without risking a free swing.

• Beginning at 3rd level, in Owl Form you are passively aware of your Favored Enemies within a mile of you.

    • This is increased to 6 miles in your Favored Terrains.

    • This doesn’t reveal where they are exactly, but will give you a general direction to hunt in.

• You have significant experience studying, tracking, hunting, and even talking to undead creatures.

    • You have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track this Favored Enemy, as well as on Intelligence checks to recall information about them.

    • When you gain this feature, you also become an expert in the languages of your choice that are spoken by this Favored Enemy, if they speak one at all.

      • In this case the Necromancer’s undead language: Necron

    • When rolling damage against this Favored Enemy you may add +2 unavoidable damage to the roll.

• You are particularly familiar with Forests and are adept at traveling and surviving in such regions.

    • When you make an Intelligence or Wisdom check related to your favored terrain, your proficiency bonus is doubled if you are using a skill that you’re proficient in.

    • While traveling in this favored terrain, you gain the following benefits:

      • Nonmagical difficult terrain doesn’t slow your group’s travel outside of combat.

      • You ignore nonmagical difficult terrain in and out of combat.

      • Your group can’t become lost except by magical means.

      • Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.

      • If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.

      • When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.

      • While tracking other creatures, you learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

      • You choose additional favored terrain types at 6th and 10th level.

      • You have advantage on initiative rolls.

      • In combat, you have advantage when rolling toward creatures who haven't yet acted.

        • This applies when rolling toward your party members and your enemies.

• You are particularly familiar with Mountains and are adept at traveling and surviving in such regions.

    • When you make an Intelligence or Wisdom check related to this favored terrain, your proficiency bonus is doubled if you are using a skill that you’re proficient in.

    • While traveling in this favored terrain, you gain the following benefits:

      • Nonmagical difficult terrain doesn’t slow your group’s travel outside of combat.

      • You ignore nonmagical difficult terrain in and out of combat.

      • Your group can’t become lost except by magical means.

      • Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.

      • If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.

      • When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.

      • While tracking other creatures, you learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

      • You choose additional favored terrain types at 6th and 10th level.

      • You have advantage on initiative rolls.

      • In combat, you have advantage when rolling toward creatures who haven't yet acted.

        • This applies when rolling toward your party members and your enemies.

• During their initiative, Myra can speak directly into Fenrir's mind through their Spiritual Bond to give Fenrir commands.

  • Fenrir takes his turn during Myra’s initiative, before or after she takes her turn.

    • You choose each turn who goes first in order to set up combinations between the two of you.

  • You can also speak in this way to suggest it to Attack, Dash, Disengage, or Help Another.

    • Fenrir never requires your command to use its reaction, such as when making an opportunity attack.

    • Once you have the Extra Attack feature, you can make one weapon attack yourself while commanding Fenrir to take your Attack action.

    • If you don’t issue a request, Fenrir takes the Dodge action.

    • If you are incapacitated or absent, the beast acts on its own, focusing on protecting you and itself.

  • While traveling through your Favored Terrain with Fenrir, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.

  • If Fenrir dies, you may obtain another Spiritual Bond with a creature by spending 8 hours in the forest tracking down and magically bonding to it as long as it isn’t hostile to you.

    • This will either be the same type of beast as before or a different one.

• Lycanthropes are repelled by the Wolfsbane flower.

    • A lycanthrope in hybrid or beast form is poisoned while within 10 feet of a living or dried Wolfsbane flower that it can smell.

    • If Wolfsbane is applied to a weapon or ammunition, lycanthropes are damaged by the weapon as if it were Silvered.

    • A successful application of Wolfsbane lasts for 1 hour.

    • If Wolfsbane remains ingested or a Wolfsbane laced weapon/projectile remains inside you at the start of your turn, you take 1d6 damage that cannot be reduced in any way.
  • GM Notes: Remember to roll twice as you have advantage on all poison saves as a Mountain Dwarvenguard
